titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Patricia Clancy Montgomery Papers, 1973-2004
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Emma Reynolds, Aaron Kahn, and Thomas E. Powers, April-June 2006

did.abstract: Educator, founder of Clonlara School in Ann Arbor, speaker and activist on behalf of home schooling and alternative methods of education. The collection includes files relating to Clonlara School and to the Clonlara Home Based Education Program, as well as to Montgomery’s work with various organizations, including the National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools and the National Homeschool Association.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Patricia Montgomery (donor no. 9707) in 2006 in two separate accessions.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Patricia Clancy Montgomery Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Patricia Montgomery was born October 13, 1934 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. A life-long teacher, she began her teaching career as a nun with the Sisters of Divine Providence in various schools in Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Michigan (1953-1961). She received her Bachelor of Education from Duquesne in 1961, then went on to teach in Westland and Ann Arbor, Michigan. She received her Master of Arts in Education in 1967 from the University of Michigan. At this time, she determined to establish an elementary school to be an alternative to the public school system. Her school, she believed, would encourage humane and non-structured education. The result was the founding and establishment of Clonlara School, a "free school" based on the Summerhill school of A. S. Neill. Beginning first as pre-school, Clonlara soon became a full elementary school, and then later a high school.

The success of Clonlara and the encouragement that she received led Montgomery to develop the Clonlara Home Based Education Program that other like-minded individuals could incorporate into their own community or home schooling efforts. The need for a network for those engaged in the alternative schooling movement also spurred Montgomery and others to establish the National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools.

Publicity about Clonlara drew attention from journalists and teachers both nationally (e.g. appearances on the Donahue program) and internationally (the visit of a Japanese television news crew to Ann Arbor). Montgomery was called upon for numerous speaking engagements and television appearances; she wrote frequently on topics of home-schooling and non-traditional educational methods; and she corresponded with educators, students, and others who shared her philosophy.

scopecontent.p: The Patricia Clancy Montgomery papers include files relating to Clonlara School and to the Clonlara Home Based Education Program, as well as to Montgomery’s work with various organizations, including the National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools and the National Homeschool Association. The collection has been arranged into the following series: Biographical, Writings, and Personal; Clonlara School; Clonlara School Outreach to Japan; Clonlara School Litigation; Legislation; People file; Organization file; National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools; Home Schooling Background Material; Clonlara School Home Based Education Program; The Learning Edge newsletter; Videocassettes; and Audiocassettes.

scopecontent.p: The Biographical, Writings and Personal series contains a variety of documents pertaining to the life and career of Patricia Montgomery. There is a wealth of articles and press materials relating to Montgomery and the Clonlara School, including several documents written by Montgomery herself. These materials span from the 1970s through to the early 1990s. Of special interest are the various interviews with Montgomery, including a transcript from a 1981 appearance on the Phil Donahue show. The series also contains a variety of background biographical information, and personal correspondence with friends and colleagues, as well as two folders containing letters to and from Patricia Montgomery's daughter Chandra and son Chai. Of further note, are the six folders chronicling her work as a mentor to students at Columbia Pacific University.

odd.p: (PM was mentor to students writing on topics of education)

scopecontent.p: Administrative materials make up the bulk of the Clonlara School series. Such documents include articles of incorporation filed with the State of Michigan, financial materials of the organization, meeting notes of the management council, information relating to school curriculum, statistical documents from the 1970s into the 2000s, and a variety of other planning records. The series also consists of Clonlara program and teacher training materials, and documents relating to national and international affiliated schools. Public relations pamphlets and other publications are also featured.

odd.p: (filing with the State Board of Education)

did.unittitle: Clonlara international affiliates (including Korea, Sweden, and Bermuda)
Individualized Curriculum and secondary academics curriculum
Questionnaire sent out to former parents of students and to former students 1993
Teacher orientation materials 1977, 1979, 1998 and unknown dates

scopecontent.p: The Clonlara School Outreach to Japan series documents Patricia Montgomery's visits to Japan and reception of Japanese delegates to Ann Arbor in 1982 and 1983, as well as the termination of the partnership between Clonlara and one Japanese school in 2000. Correspondence between Montgomery and Japanese teachers and students are included in the series.

did.unittitle: Visit of PM to Japanese schools and educators July-August 1982
Visit of Japanese television documentary producers to Clonlara 1982
Visit of Japanese teachers to Clonlara 1983

odd.p: (includes subsequent correspondence with these and other teachers and educators)

did.unittitle: Draft and background material for book on Japanese education written with Claire Korn entitled "Free Schools, Reality and Dream"
8th International Democratic Education Conference in Japan July 2000

scopecontent.p: The Clonlara School Litigation series is composed of legal documents regarding a number of civil actions brought by Clonlara Inc. and associated individuals against local and state level education officials over the way in which the State Board of Education dealt with the issue of home schooling. Included are the depositions made by Montgomery and the correspondence she had with her attorney.

did.unittitle: Clonlara, Inc., John and Sandra Bennett, Leonard and Julia Kuhar v. Michigan State Board of Education et al AND Clonlara, Inc. Robert Gibson and Cynthia Gibson and Deborah McConnell v. Michigan State Board of Education et al.

scopecontent.p: Bills affecting the nature and status of alternative and home schools can be found in the Legislation series of the collection. These legislative materials date from about 1994-1996. Also included are responses from both Clonlara and other homeschooling organizations, as well as correspondence with lawmakers, media materials and other publications regarding the proposed laws.

odd.p: (proposed amendment to require teacher certification in subject area)

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Coalition of National Homeschooling Organizations

odd.p: (removes home schools from nonpublic school status, meaning they no longer qualify for services provided to nonpublic schools)

scopecontent.p: The People File series is a collection of correspondence and other documents pertaining to Montgomery's colleagues in the local, statewide, and national alternative schools movement. The series is ordered alphabetically by the individual's last name, and in a large number of instances, the organization the person is affiliated with is noted parenthetically in the finding aid list. For more information, and related materials, the researcher should consult The National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools.

odd.p: (The Little Red home School House home education supplies)
(re amicus brief filed on behalf of NCACS in the case of Aguilar v. Felton)

scopecontent.p: The Organizational File series is composed of correspondence, publications, and other documents pertaining to alternative education organizations throughout the country. Time periods for these documents are noted in the file listing.

did.unittitle: Council for American Private Education (CAPE), Exemplary Private School Recognition Project 1983-1985
International Alternative Schools Workshop and Conference 1995
National Association for the Legal Support of Alternative Schools (NALSAS) 1989-2001
Networking Organization for Independent Schools and Educators (NOISE)
National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools (NCACS) 1980-2001

scopecontent.p: The series of the National Coalition of Alternative Community Schools contains the administrative records of the NCACS. Included are organizational bylaws, files from group conferences and retreats, correspondence of Patricia Montgomery as well as other members, proposals, instructional materials, articles, and member information. The time period for this series starts in 1980 and concludes with 2001.

did.unittitle: Article: "The Future is Now! A Profile of a National Organization," November 3, 1987

scopecontent.p: The Home Schooling Background Material series is several folders containing an assortment of source documents, primarily press clippings, which were used by Montgomery throughout her work.

The Clonlara Home Based Educational Program series documents the administrative and planning aspects of Clonlara's outreach training program. These materials, primarily conference information, correspondence, and brochures, date from the mid-1980s to roughly 1996.

did.unittitle: Seminars: Canton, Toledo, Traverse City, and Lansing 1987
Seminars: Flint, Detroit, Chicago, and Cleveland 1988

scopecontent.p: The Learning Edge is the newsletter of the Home Based Education Program and Clonlara School. The series contains issues from April of 1984 to April of 2006. The researcher should be aware, however, that some months are missing issues.
The videocassettes include a number of instructional and promotional videos on the topic of alternative education.

did.unittitle: Promotion video for Homebased Education Program
"Maui Visions: The 1993 Trans-Pacific Conference on Educational Change"

scopecontent.p: The audiocassettes include speeches of, and interviews with, Montgomery. Other cassettes contain information about home schooling.
